summary: Varys Theory
body:
Varys Theory

So you guys remember when Varys said something like “maybe the person that doesn’t want to be King is the best choice” and we all assumed it was Jon?

Well, don’t forget about the scene between Bran and Tyrion when Bran says he doesn’t wanna be Lord of Winterfell and Tyrion replies with blah blah blah I can’t remember (sorry).

Basically: Bran will be King, Tyrion or Sansa will be his hand (likely Tyrion since Sansa wants to be the Warden of the North and the Lady of Winterfell— the true power of the North).

That’s it. That’s what I want. If Jon sits on the throne I’ll hate it even more than I already do. I love Jon as a character, but come on…

blog.description: This is my ASOIAF/GOT only blog.

tags: i just needed to vent okk
you can interpret this as either platonic or romantic idk
summary: I know this doesnt matter to most people in the GOT fandom but I really fucking hate the way they undermined Jon and Arya's...
body:
I know this doesnt matter to most people in the GOT fandom but I really fucking hate the way they undermined Jon and Arya’s relationship. It’s very depressing how they rarely mention each other, barely have any screentime together, how little impact they have in each others story when in canon they’re supposed to be each others home and heart. It’s the unconditional love these two have for one another that sheds light into the violent world the books have portrayed. Both of them are literally willing to kill and die for another if they have to,,,and all of THAT its reduced to complete indifference???? Doesnt any of that mean anything???Like all D&D have done so far is remind the audience that their relationship is supposed to be special in interviews once or twice,,,and that’s it. Literally.

Like I said, I know most people in the fandom dont seem to care about Jon and Arya’s bond or Arya or even Jon to point this out but it’s truly tragic how they swept this meaningful relationship under the rug.

Harry Potter; either way is awesome. Ron/Hermione are where it's at. will read anything and everything. tv junkie. Game of Thrones. completely heart the bbc. love musicals and plays, would see one everyday if I could. lover of travel. definitely left a little of my heart in NYC.

tags: im just trying to find a compromise to my agony and pain
summary: So before you all throw rocks at me : I'm not trying to say I'm happy with the latest leaks. However I'm trying to find the...
body:
So before you all throw rocks at me : I’m not trying to say I’m happy with the latest leaks. However I’m trying to find the middle ground.

For Arya leaving and sailing certain things need to happen to make this decision understandable.

  • Discussing with her siblings and letting them know , that’s not definitive farewell but she is young and wants to see the world now that the war is over.
  • Have a scene with Gendry ,leaving the idea open that one day if they are both in the same place and she is there they will work out the obstacles of being together. Arya finally in a place where chaos and war is not her life and she feels safe and Gendry able to use a fork and lead. Both being sure what they have is more than the heat of the moment and a sweet reunion
  • This trip is not a suicide mission and parallels Nymeria getting her people relocated to safety .

I’m not saying Arya leaving makes sense but considering the relationships in the show and how it ends is not the most depressing thing if they settle it properly.

  • Bran will be king and has a council to advise him
  • Sansa will be safe back home
  • Jon is going to be with Tormund and ghost so he doesn’t need her
  • All of their enemies are dead gone and her list is gone as well.

I understand not going back to Winterfell, she is not a lady and her sister manages well . But in KL she could help Bran but maybe she feels he doesn’t need a super assassin since the war is over . Maybe her PTSD doesn’t let her stay in there. I think being in Storms End was the perfect place but again, she is not ready yet. That’s why I’m saying that a convo with Gendry is important. But I have my hope drawn so maybe I should consider this as canon and never watch the finale , D&D are too lazy to actually allow the audience a way to understand why someone needs to get a vacation.

summary: Arya Stark really spent most of her life alone in the world and traumatized... only to end up... still alone in the world and...
body:
Arya Stark really spent most of her life alone in the world and traumatized… only to end up… still alone in the world and still traumatized, without her family, away from her home, with no one to love her and that she can love in return.

The disservice and disrespect to her character and the inability to look past the “assassin” surface to see all the complexity beneath is honestly disheartening.

This show never understood her character and it never deserved it either, she is just too much for their narrow minds.

summary: Game of Thrones Recap: It Tolls for Thee
title: Game of Thrones Recap: It Tolls for Thee
excerpt: A massively uneven, occasionally brilliant episode drags down not one but two queens.
description:
What matters isn’t whether Daenerys lives up to some 21st-century ideal of a female conqueress who slays the patriarchy in a feel-good one-two dragon-claw punch. And good God, who would really want that? It’s just as flat and uninspired an idea as the emo boy who’s a secret prince. (Also, repeat after me: This does not mean that Jon Snow becomes king.) What matters is that Daenerys’s snarly hell-raising is in keeping with the character we’ve known since she ate a horse heart to satisfy her warlord husband. Her propensity for blood was always tempered by the advisers who pleaded with her for mercy, who reminded her of what she might become if she gave in to the desire for fire and blood. Now they’re all dead, and King’s Landing, we can safely assume, is no longer strictly habitable

… It was satisfying and unexpected for Arya, who had slowly devolved into nothing more than a ruthless assassin, to return to a place of tender humanity with the opposite of her surefootedness in the Battle of Winterfell.

…While I wish Cersei — by far the most dynamic and interesting woman on the show — had been given more to do than moodily stare out a very high window all season, Lena Headey worked magic with what she was given, teaching a master class in staying completely still, saying nothing, and giving a marvelous performance. After all, Cersei didn’t just lose the throne, she capsized the richest and most powerful family in Westeros and let the entire city burn. Her descent, then, from the highest tower to the depths of Maegor’s Holdfast, worked as a fitting metaphor for just how catastrophically she’s fallen, now left among the bones of long-dead dragons.

And while I admittedly hoped for a more eye-bulging ending — like Jaime’s golden hand crushing her windpipe — the collapse of a castle upon her head worked pretty damn great, too. (Rather potent revenge for a woman who blows up buildings.) Was Cersei and Jaime’s love disgusting and wrong? Hell yes, but honestly, it was also pretty true. Jaime’s arc toward redemption wasn’t cut short by his return to Cersei’s side, it was magnified by his refusal to let her die alone, his belief in the inherent value of her person, even if she’d murdered and screwed and backstabbed her way through life.

What matters isn’t whether Daenerys lives up to some 21st-century ideal of a female conqueress who slays the patriarchy in a feel-good one-two dragon-claw punch. And good God, who would really want that? It’s just as flat and uninspired an idea as the emo boy who’s a secret prince. (Also, repeat after me: This does not mean that Jon Snow becomes king.) What matters is that Daenerys’s snarly hell-raising is in keeping with the character we’ve known since she ate a horse heart to satisfy her warlord husband. Her propensity for blood was always tempered by the advisers who pleaded with her for mercy, who reminded her of what she might become if she gave in to the desire for fire and blood. Now they’re all dead, and King’s Landing, we can safely assume, is no longer strictly habitable

… It was satisfying and unexpected for Arya, who had slowly devolved into nothing more than a ruthless assassin, to return to a place of tender humanity with the opposite of her surefootedness in the Battle of Winterfell.

…While I wish Cersei — by far the most dynamic and interesting woman on the show — had been given more to do than moodily stare out a very high window all season, Lena Headey worked magic with what she was given, teaching a master class in staying completely still, saying nothing, and giving a marvelous performance. After all, Cersei didn’t just lose the throne, she capsized the richest and most powerful family in Westeros and let the entire city burn. Her descent, then, from the highest tower to the depths of Maegor’s Holdfast, worked as a fitting metaphor for just how catastrophically she’s fallen, now left among the bones of long-dead dragons.

And while I admittedly hoped for a more eye-bulging ending — like Jaime’s golden hand crushing her windpipe — the collapse of a castle upon her head worked pretty damn great, too. (Rather potent revenge for a woman who blows up buildings.) Was Cersei and Jaime’s love disgusting and wrong? Hell yes, but honestly, it was also pretty true. Jaime’s arc toward redemption wasn’t cut short by his return to Cersei’s side, it was magnified by his refusal to let her die alone, his belief in the inherent value of her person, even if she’d murdered and screwed and backstabbed her way through life.
trail.content:
What matters isn’t whether Daenerys lives up to some 21st-century ideal of a female conqueress who slays the patriarchy in a feel-good one-two dragon-claw punch. And good God, who would really want that? It’s just as flat and uninspired an idea as the emo boy who’s a secret prince. (Also, repeat after me: This does not mean that Jon Snow becomes king.) What matters is that Daenerys’s snarly hell-raising is in keeping with the character we’ve known since she ate a horse heart to satisfy her warlord husband. Her propensity for blood was always tempered by the advisers who pleaded with her for mercy, who reminded her of what she might become if she gave in to the desire for fire and blood. Now they’re all dead, and King’s Landing, we can safely assume, is no longer strictly habitable

… It was satisfying and unexpected for Arya, who had slowly devolved into nothing more than a ruthless assassin, to return to a place of tender humanity with the opposite of her surefootedness in the Battle of Winterfell.

…While I wish Cersei — by far the most dynamic and interesting woman on the show — had been given more to do than moodily stare out a very high window all season, Lena Headey worked magic with what she was given, teaching a master class in staying completely still, saying nothing, and giving a marvelous performance. After all, Cersei didn’t just lose the throne, she capsized the richest and most powerful family in Westeros and let the entire city burn. Her descent, then, from the highest tower to the depths of Maegor’s Holdfast, worked as a fitting metaphor for just how catastrophically she’s fallen, now left among the bones of long-dead dragons.

And while I admittedly hoped for a more eye-bulging ending — like Jaime’s golden hand crushing her windpipe — the collapse of a castle upon her head worked pretty damn great, too. (Rather potent revenge for a woman who blows up buildings.) Was Cersei and Jaime’s love disgusting and wrong? Hell yes, but honestly, it was also pretty true. Jaime’s arc toward redemption wasn’t cut short by his return to Cersei’s side, it was magnified by his refusal to let her die alone, his belief in the inherent value of her person, even if she’d murdered and screwed and backstabbed her way through life.

blog.name: samaraclegane
blog.title: fem
blog.description: caroline dhavernas is my wife. always feel free to send me prompts!

summary: First of all, LOVE EVERYTHING YOU WRITE. second, can you do a post 8x05 fic where Arya is just kinda over fucking whelmed by...
question: First of all, LOVE EVERYTHING YOU WRITE. second, can you do a post 8x05 fic where Arya is just kinda over fucking whelmed by Sandor’s death and the destruction that dany caused, and Jon finds her and they kind of help each other? Like Jon helps Arya find herself again, while learning about what she is capable of, and Arya helps Jon come to terms with who he is and the fact that his gf is bananas?
answer:
author’s note: thank you so much anon!! apologies this has been sitting for a short while, I read it initially and thought it was so good I’d take some time on it! hope it’s good enough for you (and not too heavily metaphor-based haha, it’s a problem I have) :)

-she’s shaking. even as she rides off, she can’t get the images of Sandor’s undoubted final moments out of her mind, and the sight of that little girl, burnt to a crisp beside the ashes that were previously - mere moments before - her mother. the white horse stained red, crimson with memories, bleeding with truths that had only just come to light.

-it’s later, now. she still has nightmares about that day, and suspects she always will. then again, if there’s one place that’ll always be home, it’s Winterfell. its high walls and stony appearance reminds her of him - its strength and build paternal, the image of her father, Lord Eddard Stark. and then the godswood, beautiful and endlessly intelligent, spilling with auburn leaves year-round. that, the cozy tree, is her mother.

-except now, it’s not. she’s sat beneath it and though she can vividly recall how she had once perceived it, it’s not the same. back in Braavos she had longed for this moment, where she could physically sit beneath the branches and watch the sky through the spaces in the leaves, but now she’s doing it, it just feels empty. she knows too much has happened - so much has changed - and they’ve seen none of it; they’re gone.

-the breaking of snow snaps her focus. she swivels where she sits and sees Jon approaching. he’s not quite smiling, but he seems happy to see her. a familiar face, at least, is a nice thing to witness after such trauma - she can say that with first-hand experience.

-”thought I might find you here,” he says gravelly, sounding as though he’s been screaming for years on end, “you always did love the godswood.”

-Arya could almost laugh, and almost cry. she wishes things could be the way they used to be, even with Old Nan’s stories of things she’s now seen with her own eyes and Sansa picking at her for dressing like a boy. she’d take it all, if it meant going back.

-”do you ever miss it?” she asks him, looking back at the face carved into the tree trunk, “how things used to be?”

-”when I was bastard Jon Snow of house Stark?” he sounds like he’s going to laugh, but just sighs heavily and admits, “all the time.”

-”you’re Aegon Targaryen now,” she acknowledges, knowing they’re safe in this spot, even just for now, “and who am I?”

-”you’re the same person you’ve always been,” he tells her, then takes a seat beside her on the cold, protruding rock, “you’re Arya Stark of Winterfell.”

-the formality of the title makes her laugh, breaking her cold visage. she’s suddenly thrust back into Braavos, into the House of Black and White, and her smile fades.

-”am I?”

-when she looks over at Jon, he’s got an expression that tells her he’s sincerely confused. his dark brows are furrowed and, though he looks cold, she can tell that he wants to explode heated words. he’s always hated her self-doubt: he was the first to encourage her to pursue whatever lifestyle she felt best living, and she doesn’t know whether to thank him or kill him.

-”of course you are,” there’s a warmth to his voice that sends a chill through her, and she nods like he’s the one to finally get through to her. “I’m the one who should be having an identity crisis, anyhow.”

-”what’s the latest news from King’s Landing?”

-”Daenerys has kept anybody that tries to threaten her throne at bay,” he almost chokes on the name, yet soldiers on, “she has the Unsullied fighting dutifully for her night and day. it doesn’t look like anybody’s getting anywhere any time soon.”

-Arya hedges her bets, and dares to break into a cheeky grin and ask, “guess you royally messed up there.”

-he shoots her a look and she becomes nervous, only when he looks away he begins to laugh himself, and her fears dissipate into nothingness. she should have known, really: he’s always been her brother, regardless of titles or families, and he’s the only one to ever truly understand her for who she is, and why she does the things she does.

-”yeah, I guess I did,” he continues chuckling, and they laugh together like it’s something funny, like it doesn’t have the potential to be a life-threatening, world-shaking catastrophe.

-she follows the outline of his face, then looks off into the distance again, speaking to both him and herself as she absently promises, “we’ll get there one day, Jon, in some roundabout way. it’s what our family does.”

-there’s no question of her choice of words from either of them. there’s just a period of silence that follows, both wallowing in mutual acceptance, knowing the future is dangerous and exciting - having felt it, witnessed it in their own lives, seen the shapes it makes things take - and then, there, she realises something.

-Winterfell isn’t hollow. even without her parents to guide her, she isn’t alone. their spirits have moved on, and the souls that have taken the vacant places in the trees and walls are alive ones now, like she hasn’t heard for centuries. 

the firm, hard walls aren’t her father, they’re Jon. they’re brutal when they need to be, but they keep their loved ones close, and though they’ve burnt before they dare to keep fighting and loving and carrying on forth with life, because that’s how things work up here.

-and the leaves, they’re Sansa. they’re elegant and bright and clever, and she’s never trusted the judgement of anything more than she does them. they’ve seen everything, they’ve fallen in and out and up and down, they’ve seen the world and how the people in in work - both in mysterious and kind ways - and they’re come back here, chosen to return home, to here, to Winterfell, to her.

-she smiles privately, and can’t help but think just how lucky she is. she isn’t alone - she’s never been - she just has to look a little harder to find the ones who’ll support her through anything and everything. and, if her luck doesn’t run out, she might just begin to accept all of the changes that have come her way.

summary: What I think a lot of people miss is how much Dany and Arya are foils for each other. The series doesn’t show Dany’s back story....
body:
What I think a lot of people miss is how much Dany and Arya are foils for each other. The series doesn’t show Dany’s back story. From what I understand, Dany and Viserys have a very tough time after the death of their father and mother. They wandered Essos and went from place to place, surviving on the hospitality of others. They had no home. They were at the mercy of others who opened their home to them on the expectation that one day their family would rise to power again.

When we meet Dany at the beginning of the show, she and Viserys are in a desperate place. They have maybe run out of generosity and basically trade Dany to have some leverage for themselves to survive. Once Dany loses Drogo, she is again without a place in the world, unless she makes one for herself. Like Arya after Ned’s death, she has to find something to hold onto. Some giant goal that she will pursue with blinders so that she can make it through the uncertainty and come out on top.

Both Dany and Arya are seeking power so that they may have a place in the world and protect themselves. There comes a place where both feel like they have no family left in the world to turn to. This is where their paths diverge, and create a foil.

Dany gets the power to kill handed to her by fate when she hatched the dragons. Arya also seeks out the power to kill, but she is an apprentice of death. Her journey involves learning rules of balance and rules of restraint in the House of Black and White.

Danny’s tragic flaw is that she fails to comprehend that only death can pay for life, and vice versa. Or, that she is willing to agree to those terms. You can’t have one without the other. It’s the House of Black AND White. Arya does not receive the power to kill until she has learned to also temper her killer instincts.

There is a wonderful parallel in the last episode where both Dany and Arya have within their reach the dreams that they first committed themselves to and have been striving towards since the moment their lost their place in the world and needed something to hold onto. However, Arya has the perspective to walk away from her childhood goals, because she has had lessons in tempering her instincts and understands the rules of balance and the true costs of taking lives.

Dany’s journey has not included an education in applying her killing power. Both Arya and Dany use death to deliver justice, so long as their paths run parallel, however there is more to death than justice. There are natural laws and consequences that govern the taking of a life, which have nothing to do with justice. Arya is willing to let go of her dream of assasinating Cersei, because Arya is not willing to pay the costs associated (I guess, giving her own life). Dany chooses differently.

blog.name: 04nbod
blog.title: Letters to Krypton
blog.description: A Damn Dirty Fandom blog! Old as fuck, proper old school fandom here. I remember the Doctor Who Wilderness years when the BBC showed Buffy and Roswell to fill the void in our baby hearts! British, I look at things in British-y ways. Anglophiles are beloved here. #Ancientandforever

blog.name: yahoder
blog.description: "A reader lives a thousand lives before he dies.The man who never reads lives only one." - George RR Martin

summary: So, Daenerys (a grown ass woman who has already buried a husband, a child and several other people with emotional grace) sees...
body:
So, Daenerys (a grown ass woman who has already buried a husband, a child and several other people with emotional grace) sees her best friend unjustly beheaded and she goes crazy.

Meanwhile, Arya sees HER FATHER unjustly beheaded (in addition to having her mother, two brothers and other important figures die) AS A CHILD becomes a perfectly functioning adult?

Okay. Right.

summary: People make fun of parents for naming their kids after Game of Thrones characters but a lot of women named their daughters...
body: People make fun of parents for naming their kids after Game of Thrones characters but a lot of women named their daughters “Isabella” because of Twilight and that’s way fucking worse than a million girls named after Arya.
